evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: This root cause withstands potential defeaters as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the failure to issue timely challenges or stop warnings, confirming its critical role in the coordination failure.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of communication breakdowns, including divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent among crew members and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, within the hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified root cause is resistant to common defeaters as it is supported by clear evidence of non-compliance at the TRP, and the resulting physical contact with the blast-fence confirms the procedural lapse.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of procedural deviations in pushback operations, specifically the failure to comply with the required TRP stop/release point, resulting in continued pushback movement until blast-fence contact.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: Visual signals and lack of warnings imply failure in challenge/alert communication
Crew roles and training imply expected awareness of TRP and stop-state
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor passed the TRP while still controlling pushback (supporting R1)
If hardware or marking deficiencies were primary causes (supporting R3)
If mechanical faults or malfunctions were documented (supporting R4)

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H4 directly document lack of timely effective challenge or stop warning despite cues, supporting the primary coordination failure claim (R2). H2 and H9 show crew roles and awareness consistent with coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication content or timing beyond visual signals; possible ambiguity in interpreting crew assumptions.

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of communication breakdowns, including divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent among crew members and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

assumptions: Crew had divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent based on lack of warnings
TRP markings were adequate and visible as per H7
defeaters: If evidence showed effective challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored
If TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting environment/marking deficiency
If mechanical faults or hardware failures were documented

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 shows no timely effective challenge or stop warning despite cues; H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP; H9 confirms crew awareness of TRP, supporting divergent assumptions and communication breakdown as root cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of crew verbal communication or explicit assumptions; reliance on inferred communication failure

node.statement: This root cause withstands potential defeaters as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the failure to issue timely challenges or stop warnings, confirming its critical role in the coordination failure.

assumptions: Lack of warnings or challenges implies failure in communication rather than mechanical issues.
Trainee's awareness of TRP suggests that misunderstanding or failure to communicate was the key factor.
defeaters: If evidence showed fault codes, tests, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical control failure (R4), this would challenge the dominance of R2.
If warnings or challenges had been timely and effective, undermining the claim of communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 indicates no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the presence of communication breakdown (R2). H9 confirms awareness of TRP, implying divergent assumptions or failure to communicate effectively rather than mechanical failure (R4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure is present, but absence of such evidence does not fully exclude it.

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, within the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The TRP was adequately marked and visible as per standard airport procedures (supported indirectly by H7).
The tug instructor was in control and aware of the TRP location during pushback.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or inadequately marked to the tug instructor or driver, or if mechanical failure prevented stopping, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4) directly documents the pushback continuing beyond the TRP with the tug instructor actively driving (H3), and the instructor's own statement (H8) indicates no warning was given and the visual stop signal was insufficient, supporting the claim of a procedural lapse rather than environmental or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of TRP visibility or marking adequacy is provided; reliance on instructor statements and observed behavior introduces some ambiguity.

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of procedural deviations in pushback operations, specifically the failure to comply with the required TRP stop/release point, resulting in continued pushback movement until blast-fence contact.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings were visible and known to the tug instructor
No mechanical faults prevented stopping at the TRP
Communication of stop requirements was adequate and understood
defeaters: If evidence showed a verified mechanical fault preventing stopping at TRP
If evidence indicated the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to explain the miss
If evidence showed the stop command was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP and continued until collision, supporting the procedural deviation claim. H3 and H8 confirm the tug instructor was actively controlling pushback and did not receive warnings, reinforcing failure to stop at TRP was due to procedural lapse rather than mechanical or communication failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in whether communication or environment factors contributed, but evidence favors procedural deviation

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and reproducible in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period, supported by tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, given the corroboration from tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affect stopping performance, as observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified scope.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, confirming that the TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement was inadequate at that time.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion that the TRP marking deficiency caused or materially enabled the TRP miss is robust against potential defeaters, as alternative explanations or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context do not sufficiently undermine the identified environmental or marking inadequacy.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement aligns with the key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context, accurately reflecting the conditions that plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and reproducible in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period, supported by tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences.

assumptions: No direct evidence of mechanical or control-system failure is present in the provided history items.
The incident is attributed primarily to procedural and communication failures rather than mechanical faults.
defeaters: If fault codes, diagnostic tests, or repeatable failure signatures were presented showing mechanical or control-system malfunction during the incident period, this would support the claim.
If evidence of hardware or control system faults causing the failure were found, it would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast barrier despite no reported mechanical or control-system failure; communication and procedural issues (H1, H2, H3, H8) suggest human factors rather than reproducible mechanical faults, contradicting the claim of consistent detectable mechanical/control failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, confirming that the TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement was inadequate at that time.

assumptions: The 14.97 m clearance and TRP location imply the marking was present but do not confirm its visibility or prominence.
The tug instructor's comments about visual signal insufficiency imply marking or environmental deficiencies affecting recognition.
defeaters: Direct evidence of clear, prominent, and adequately placed TRP markings during the timeframe would change my mind.
Evidence that crew recognized and expected the TRP but procedural deviations caused the miss would favor R1 over R3.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H7 establishes the TRP location and clearance, implying marking presence; H8 indicates visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, suggesting marking visibility or prominence was inadequate to prevent the miss, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly describing the TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement during the incident timeframe; reliance on indirect inference from procedural and observational statements.

node.statement: The identified root cause is resistant to common defeaters as it is supported by clear evidence of non-compliance at the TRP, and the resulting physical contact with the blast-fence confirms the procedural lapse.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and clearance are correctly identified and understood by the tug instructor.
The lack of warning signals from wingman or headset operator implies no effective communication breakdown that would explain the pushback beyond TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP stop state was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor before passing the TRP, or if the collision was caused by mechanical failure rather than procedural lapse.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the pushback continued beyond the TRP causing collision, H7 confirms TRP location and clearance, and H8 indicates no effective warning was given, supporting the procedural deviation root cause and its resistance to communication breakdown defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and situational awareness of the tug instructor and crew.

node.statement: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affect stopping performance, as observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified scope.

assumptions: Passing the TRP and collision despite engine idle implies a braking or control malfunction affecting stopping performance.
No warnings or effective stop signals contributed to failure to stop, indicating control system or mechanical issues rather than solely environment or procedural causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective braking or control inputs were made and failed due to environment or marking deficiencies, or if tests/diagnostics confirmed no mechanical faults, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided despite engine idle, indicating a control or braking malfunction affecting stopping. H8 notes limitations in visual stop signals and no warnings received, supporting a mechanical/control failure over environment or procedural causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct diagnostic or test evidence confirming mechanical/control failure; reliance on circumstantial evidence of stopping failure and procedural context

node.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement aligns with the key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context, accurately reflecting the conditions that plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss.

assumptions: The absence of warnings and the instructor's statement about visual signal limitations imply marking visibility/prominence issues.
No direct evidence of mechanical failure or procedural deviation dominating the cause is present.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and prominent to all crew members, or if a mechanical control failure was confirmed, the conclusion would change.
If procedural deviations or communication breakdowns were proven to be the dominant cause, this would reduce support for R3.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H7 shows the TRP marking and clearance exist but does not indicate deficiency; H8 indicates the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were given, supporting inadequate marking visibility/prominence/placement as a plausible cause of the TRP miss.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility/prominence was truly inadequate versus procedural or communication factors

children_spec.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify presence and control of the tug instructor through video footage, witness statements, or control logs

children_spec.statement: The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and reachable during the pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Check operational manuals, physical markers, and environmental conditions to confirm TRP visibility and accessibility

children_spec.statement: The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze pushback movement data, video evidence, or control inputs to determine if stopping at TRP was attempted or achieved

children_spec.statement: Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP until contact with the blast-fence occurred
children_spec.test_procedure: Review movement tracking data and physical damage reports to confirm pushback continued past TRP to blast-fence contact

children_spec.statement: Ground crew members were physically present and reachable during the critical time window
children_spec.test_procedure: Check logs, communications, and personnel records to confirm ground crew presence and availability at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect device maintenance records and test device functionality post-incident; review communication logs for device failures

children_spec.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary for timely challenge or stop warnings
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication channel usage and restrictions; verify if any technical or procedural barriers prevented message transmission

children_spec.statement: Ground crew were not engaged in other tasks that prevented them from noticing or responding to cues
children_spec.test_procedure: Review task assignments, workload, and situational awareness reports to determine if crew attention was diverted

node.statement: The conclusion that the TRP marking deficiency caused or materially enabled the TRP miss is robust against potential defeaters, as alternative explanations or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context do not sufficiently undermine the identified environmental or marking inadequacy.

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility and placement were inadequate enough to plausibly cause the miss absent crew attention lapse.
No mechanical control failure evidence is present in the packet to contradict the marking deficiency cause.
defeaters: If clear evidence showed the crew recognized the TRP and expected to stop but continued due to procedural error, this would favor R1.
If strong communication failures or warnings were documented that could explain the miss, this would favor R2.
If mechanical control failures were corroborated by evidence, this would favor R4.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 show the aircraft passed the TRP marking despite clearance, indicating marking inadequacy; H8 highlights communication and signaling limitations, supporting that alternative explanations like procedural deviation or communication breakdown do not sufficiently undermine the marking deficiency cause.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew attention and signaling effectiveness; lack of explicit evidence ruling out procedural or communication failures

node.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary for timely challenge or stop warnings

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication channels were used and warnings were timely and received by the tug instructor.
If the headset operator or wingman had clear, unobstructed communication means and actively issued stop warnings.

The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H3) shows ground crew had physical presence and communication means, but H8 indicates visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, contradicting unimpeded access to timely challenge or stop warnings.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and possible unreported verbal warnings

node.statement: The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation

defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor was absent or not in control during pushback
If mechanical failure or environment factors fully explained the TRP exceedance without instructor control

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 directly shows the tug instructor was present, took control, and was actively driving during pushback including past the TRP, supporting the claim.

node.statement: Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident

assumptions: Communication devices include headset operator and wingman communication tools.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit successful communication and warnings were given and received timely by ground crew during the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8) indicates no warning was received from wingman or headset operator, suggesting communication devices were not effectively used or functional for timely alerts, contradicting the claim. H1 confirms communication means existed but does not confirm operational effectiveness.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication devices were operational but warnings were not issued, or devices failed to function properly.

node.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, given the corroboration from tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.

assumptions: No direct diagnostic or fault code evidence is provided but mechanical failure is inferred from collision despite procedural controls.
Procedural deviations and communication breakdowns are less supported given the evidence of control system malfunction.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective procedural signals and warnings were given but ignored, or if no fault codes or diagnostics supported mechanical failure, the conclusion would be less robust.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or communication breakdowns contributed; lack of explicit diagnostic test results in evidence.

children_spec.statement: A mechanical failure occurred in the tug or aircraft control system during the incident

node.statement: Corroboration of failure exists through tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence of tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences corroborating mechanical/control failure (H4, H8, H9). Instead, evidence points to procedural and communication issues, favoring R1 over R4.

node.statement: Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP until contact with the blast-fence occurred

assumptions: No mechanical control failure occurred since none was reported or observed
Instructor was actively controlling pushback during the event
defeaters: If evidence showed verified braking or control faults causing uncontrolled movement beyond TRP
If mechanical failure signatures were documented or observed

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H4 directly states the pushback continued beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact, with H3 and H8 supporting that the instructor was actively controlling pushback and no mechanical failure was reported, favoring R1 over R4.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure; reliance on absence of malfunction reports

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect photographic or video evidence and maintenance records to confirm the presence and condition of the TRP marking at the incident time

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Review design and placement documentation and conduct field tests or simulations to assess visibility from the crew's perspective

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions (lighting, weather, obstructions) at the time did not prevent the TRP marking from being seen
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze weather reports, lighting conditions, and any potential obstructions present during the incident

children_spec.statement: The TRP marking was maintained in a condition (color, reflectivity, cleanliness) that allowed it to be visible and prominent
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine maintenance logs and physical evidence to determine the condition of the marking at the time

node.statement: The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions

assumptions: TRP marking visibility is inferred from clearance and training evidence rather than direct sighting confirmation
Crew awareness and training imply normal operational conditions for TRP visibility
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was obscured or not visible under normal conditions
If crew testimony or recordings indicated they did not see the TRP marking
If environmental conditions (e.g., lighting, weather) impaired TRP visibility

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 indicates the TRP location was defined and had sufficient clearance, suggesting visibility was adequate. H8 and H9 show the crew were trained and aware of the TRP, but procedural and communication issues limited effective stopping, favoring procedural deviation over marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct observation or measurement of TRP marking visibility during the event

node.statement: The TRP marking was maintained in a condition (color, reflectivity, cleanliness) that allowed it to be visible and prominent

defeaters: If direct evidence showed the TRP marking was faded, dirty, or otherwise not visible or prominent at the time, this would support the claim.
If witnesses reported difficulty seeing the TRP marking due to environmental conditions or marking condition.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and hit the blast barrier, indicating the marking was not sufficiently visible or prominent to stop the tug. H7 confirms adequate clearance at the TRP, implying the marking was physically present. H8 suggests communication and procedural issues rather than marking visibility caused the miss, favoring procedural deviation (R1) over marking deficiency (R3).
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence on TRP marking condition (color, reflectivity, cleanliness) at the time

node.statement: A mechanical failure occurred in the tug or aircraft control system during the incident

defeaters: Discovery of fault codes, diagnostic test results, or repeatable mechanical/control system failures would support mechanical failure.
Direct evidence of tug or aircraft control system malfunction during the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H8 describe procedural and communication issues during pushback with no direct indication of mechanical or control system failure, favoring procedural deviation or communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point

assumptions: The tug instructor was actively controlling the pushback at the time the aircraft passed the TRP.
The TRP was visible and marked adequately as per H7, so failure to stop was procedural, not environmental.
No mechanical failure prevented stopping as no such evidence is presented.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to the instructor or crew (supporting R3), or
If there was a mechanical failure preventing stopping (supporting R4), or
If communication about the TRP stop state was not shared or understood (supporting R2)

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly states the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast fence, indicating failure to stop at TRP. H5 confirms the instructor stopped the tug only after the collision. H8 supports that the instructor was controlling pushback and did not receive warnings, supporting the claim that the instructor failed to stop at TRP.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on communication clarity or mechanical failure; assumptions about instructor awareness and control are inferred.

node.statement: Ground crew members were physically present and reachable during the critical time window

defeaters: If evidence showed ground crew were absent or unreachable during the critical time window
If warnings or challenges were effectively communicated and received

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 confirms physical presence and proximity of ground crew during the critical time window; H8 indicates lack of warnings despite presence, supporting the claim of availability but communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

assumptions: The TRP was adequately marked and visible as per standard airport procedures (supported indirectly by H7).
The tug instructor was in control and aware of the TRP location during pushback.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP was not visible or inadequately marked to the tug instructor or driver, or if mechanical failure prevented stopping, this would change the conclusion.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4) directly documents the pushback continuing beyond the TRP with the tug instructor actively driving (H3), and the instructor's own statement (H8) indicates no warning was given and the visual stop signal was insufficient, supporting the claim of a procedural lapse rather than environmental or marking deficiency.
availability.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of TRP visibility or marking adequacy is provided; reliance on instructor statements and observed behavior introduces some ambiguity.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and clearance are correctly identified and understood by the tug instructor.
The lack of warning signals from wingman or headset operator implies no effective communication breakdown that would explain the pushback beyond TRP.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP stop state was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor before passing the TRP, or if the collision was caused by mechanical failure rather than procedural lapse.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the pushback continued beyond the TRP causing collision, H7 confirms TRP location and clearance, and H8 indicates no effective warning was given, supporting the procedural deviation root cause and its resistance to communication breakdown defeaters.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and situational awareness of the tug instructor and crew.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings were visible and known to the tug instructor
No mechanical faults prevented stopping at the TRP
Communication of stop requirements was adequate and understood
defeaters: If evidence showed a verified mechanical fault preventing stopping at TRP
If evidence indicated the TRP was not visible or marked adequately to explain the miss
If evidence showed the stop command was not communicated or understood by the tug instructor
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly shows the aircraft passed the TRP and continued until collision, supporting the procedural deviation claim. H3 and H8 confirm the tug instructor was actively controlling pushback and did not receive warnings, reinforcing failure to stop at TRP was due to procedural lapse rather than mechanical or communication failure.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in whether communication or environment factors contributed, but evidence favors procedural deviation

assumptions: Visual signals and lack of warnings imply failure in challenge/alert communication
Crew roles and training imply expected awareness of TRP and stop-state
defeaters: If evidence showed the tug instructor passed the TRP while still controlling pushback (supporting R1)
If hardware or marking deficiencies were primary causes (supporting R3)
If mechanical faults or malfunctions were documented (supporting R4)
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H4 directly document lack of timely effective challenge or stop warning despite cues, supporting the primary coordination failure claim (R2). H2 and H9 show crew roles and awareness consistent with coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.
availability.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication content or timing beyond visual signals; possible ambiguity in interpreting crew assumptions.

assumptions: Lack of warnings or challenges implies failure in communication rather than mechanical issues.
Trainee's awareness of TRP suggests that misunderstanding or failure to communicate was the key factor.
defeaters: If evidence showed fault codes, tests, or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical control failure (R4), this would challenge the dominance of R2.
If warnings or challenges had been timely and effective, undermining the claim of communication breakdown.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 indicates no timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues, supporting the presence of communication breakdown (R2). H9 confirms awareness of TRP, implying divergent assumptions or failure to communicate effectively rather than mechanical failure (R4).
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure is present, but absence of such evidence does not fully exclude it.

assumptions: Crew had divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent based on lack of warnings
TRP markings were adequate and visible as per H7
defeaters: If evidence showed effective challenge or stop warnings were given and ignored
If TRP markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting environment/marking deficiency
If mechanical faults or hardware failures were documented
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 shows no timely effective challenge or stop warning despite cues; H4 confirms the aircraft passed the TRP; H9 confirms crew awareness of TRP, supporting divergent assumptions and communication breakdown as root cause.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of crew verbal communication or explicit assumptions; reliance on inferred communication failure

assumptions: The 14.97 m clearance and TRP location imply the marking was present but do not confirm its visibility or prominence.
The tug instructor's comments about visual signal insufficiency imply marking or environmental deficiencies affecting recognition.
defeaters: Direct evidence of clear, prominent, and adequately placed TRP markings during the timeframe would change my mind.
Evidence that crew recognized and expected the TRP but procedural deviations caused the miss would favor R1 over R3.
availability.reasoning_summary: H7 establishes the TRP location and clearance, implying marking presence; H8 indicates visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, suggesting marking visibility or prominence was inadequate to prevent the miss, supporting the claim.
availability.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly describing the TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement during the incident timeframe; reliance on indirect inference from procedural and observational statements.

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility and placement were inadequate enough to plausibly cause the miss absent crew attention lapse.
No mechanical control failure evidence is present in the packet to contradict the marking deficiency cause.
defeaters: If clear evidence showed the crew recognized the TRP and expected to stop but continued due to procedural error, this would favor R1.
If strong communication failures or warnings were documented that could explain the miss, this would favor R2.
If mechanical control failures were corroborated by evidence, this would favor R4.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 show the aircraft passed the TRP marking despite clearance, indicating marking inadequacy; H8 highlights communication and signaling limitations, supporting that alternative explanations like procedural deviation or communication breakdown do not sufficiently undermine the marking deficiency cause.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in crew attention and signaling effectiveness; lack of explicit evidence ruling out procedural or communication failures

assumptions: The absence of warnings and the instructor's statement about visual signal limitations imply marking visibility/prominence issues.
No direct evidence of mechanical failure or procedural deviation dominating the cause is present.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and prominent to all crew members, or if a mechanical control failure was confirmed, the conclusion would change.
If procedural deviations or communication breakdowns were proven to be the dominant cause, this would reduce support for R3.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: H7 shows the TRP marking and clearance exist but does not indicate deficiency; H8 indicates the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were given, supporting inadequate marking visibility/prominence/placement as a plausible cause of the TRP miss.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility/prominence was truly inadequate versus procedural or communication factors

assumptions: No direct evidence of mechanical or control-system failure is present in the provided history items.
The incident is attributed primarily to procedural and communication failures rather than mechanical faults.
defeaters: If fault codes, diagnostic tests, or repeatable failure signatures were presented showing mechanical or control-system malfunction during the incident period, this would support the claim.
If evidence of hardware or control system faults causing the failure were found, it would change the assessment.
availability.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast barrier despite no reported mechanical or control-system failure; communication and procedural issues (H1, H2, H3, H8) suggest human factors rather than reproducible mechanical faults, contradicting the claim of consistent detectable mechanical/control failure.

assumptions: No direct diagnostic or fault code evidence is provided but mechanical failure is inferred from collision despite procedural controls.
Procedural deviations and communication breakdowns are less supported given the evidence of control system malfunction.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective procedural signals and warnings were given but ignored, or if no fault codes or diagnostics supported mechanical failure, the conclusion would be less robust.
defeater_resistance.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft continued beyond the TRP and collided despite engine idle, indicating a malfunction. H8 highlights limitations in procedural signals and lack of warnings, supporting mechanical/control failure over procedural deviation.
defeater_resistance.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or communication breakdowns contributed; lack of explicit diagnostic test results in evidence.

assumptions: Passing the TRP and collision despite engine idle implies a braking or control malfunction affecting stopping performance.
No warnings or effective stop signals contributed to failure to stop, indicating control system or mechanical issues rather than solely environment or procedural causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective braking or control inputs were made and failed due to environment or marking deficiencies, or if tests/diagnostics confirmed no mechanical faults, this would change the assessment.
fit_to_key_features.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided despite engine idle, indicating a control or braking malfunction affecting stopping. H8 notes limitations in visual stop signals and no warnings received, supporting a mechanical/control failure over environment or procedural causes.
fit_to_key_features.uncertainty_source: lack of direct diagnostic or test evidence confirming mechanical/control failure; reliance on circumstantial evidence of stopping failure and procedural context

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:availab.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, within the hist_t2_interim scope.
The active tug instructor was present and in control during the pushback operation
Pushback movement continued beyond the TRP until contact with the blast-fence occurred
The tug instructor failed to stop the pushback movement at the TRP stop/release point
The TRP stop/release point was clearly defined and reachable during the pushback

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:defeate.statement: The identified root cause is resistant to common defeaters as it is supported by clear evidence of non-compliance at the TRP, and the resulting physical contact with the blast-fence confirms the procedural lapse.

R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION:fit_to_.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of procedural deviations in pushback operations, specifically the failure to comply with the required TRP stop/release point, resulting in continued pushback movement until blast-fence contact.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as documented in the hist_t2_interim scope.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:availability:.statement: Ground crew had unimpeded access to communication channels necessary for timely challenge or stop warnings
Communication devices used by ground crew were operational and functional during the incident
Ground crew members were physically present and reachable during the critical time window
Ground crew were not engaged in other tasks that prevented them from noticing or responding to cues

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:defeater_resi.statement: This root cause withstands potential defeaters as no evidence contradicts the presence of divergent assumptions or the failure to issue timely challenges or stop warnings, confirming its critical role in the coordination failure.

R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN:fit_to_key_fe.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of communication breakdowns, including divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent among crew members and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:ava.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, confirming that the TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement was inadequate at that time.
The TRP marking was placed in a location that should have been visible to the flight crew under normal operational conditions
The TRP marking was maintained in a condition (color, reflectivity, cleanliness) that allowed it to be visible and prominent
Environmental conditions (lighting, weather, obstructions) at the time did not prevent the TRP marking from being seen
The TRP marking was physically present and not obscured or removed at the time of the incident

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:def.statement: The conclusion that the TRP marking deficiency caused or materially enabled the TRP miss is robust against potential defeaters, as alternative explanations or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context do not sufficiently undermine the identified environmental or marking inadequacy.

R3_ENVIRONMENT_OR_MARKING_DEFICIENCY:fit.statement: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, or placement aligns with the key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context, accurately reflecting the conditions that plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:availabili.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and reproducible in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period, supported by tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences.
Corroboration of failure exists through tests, diagnostics, or repeat failure occurrences
A mechanical failure occurred in the tug or aircraft control system during the incident
Control or braking malfunction directly affected the stopping capability of the aircraft or tug

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:defeater_r.statement: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, given the corroboration from tests, diagnostics, and repeat failures within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context.

R4_MECHANICAL_CONTROL_FAILURE:fit_to_key.statement: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions that affect stopping performance, as observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified scope.
